comment.author: 62379908@N00
comment._content:
Interesting old aircraft here.  The two in the background are probably Douglas DC-3's.  The larger plane in the foreground also has a Douglas look.  Could be a DC-4 or DC-6.  It has tricycle gear, while the others are tail-draggers. I can see the American Airlines logo on the fuselage near the tail, but the name spelled out includeds the word "overseas."  I wonder if the 1947 date might be a bit early.

I just did a little research and the DC-4 is a pre-war design and could easily have been flying across oceans in 1947.  Pictures show tricycle gear, with two tires and each side.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Here are some notes about the Swedish Air Lines Douglas DC-3 www.flying-vikings.net/dc-3-fleet.html SE BBO Orvar Viking, c/n 13637, with SAS 1948-1957, Broken up 1968. SE BAA Arne Viking, c/n 1947, with SAS 1948-1953, Crashed Congo 1961. Another website shows SE BBO flew with other airlines www.oy-reg.dk/register/2113.html Here are more photos of SE BAA f-104.net/dakota/dakotasve/1947/1947.html

comment.author: 95813463@N03
comment._content: Nice to see a color shot from this era. I hate B&W. Is that some kind of support holding the tail up on the DC-4?

comment.author: 25695066@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/95813463@N03] 
The tail support / tail pole was put in place so the aircraft would not tip back on its tail during the loading/unloading of cargo and/or passengers from the rear of the aircraft.  In fact, it was important for passengers to remain seated and not rush to the aft exit of the DC-4 until the support was put in place by the ground crew.

comment._content: thanks,TVL1970, I gotta think that's a little scary that she's that tail heavy.
